newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Elekta says Philips unit costs $65 mln.
newsitem.headline: Elekta says Philips unit costs $65 mln.

text.p: Swedish medical instruments company Elekta AB, known for its gamma knife, said on Wednesday that the costs for acquiring the non-invasive surgery unit of Philips are estimated to amount to $65 million.
On top of that price may come an additional sum, conditional on the unit's 1997 order intake, Elekta said in its interim report.
The acquisition, which will cause a significant goodwill, will be financed through a new share issue and bank loans, the company said.
Philips and Elekta have a preliminary agreement about the transfer of the unit. Negotiations are expected to be finalized at the beginning of 1997.
If the deal goes through, Philips will hold about 10 percent of Elekta's equity through a directed share issue.

Elekta also plans a general share issue whether or not the deal goes through, but the issue will be larger if the acquisition is finalized, said Elekta spokesman Sverker Littorin at the company's capital market day on Wednesday.

An integration between Philip's unit and Elekta's operations is expected to give an increase in sales of 150 million crowns annually for Elekta's current products within non-invasive surgery and non-invasive therapy, Elekta said.
